facts.text: Civil Appeal No. 78 of 1962 filed in Supreme Court.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Civil Appeal No. 78 of 1962. Appeal from the judgment and order dated April 13,1960, of the

facts.text: Appeal from judgment and order dated April 13,1960 of Bombay High Court in Income-tax Reference No 40 of 1959.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal from the judgment and order dated April 13,1960, of the Bombay High Court in Income-tax Reference No 40 of 1959.

facts.text: Judgment of Supreme Court delivered on November 25, 1963 by SARKAR J.

anchor.surface_text: November 25, 1963. The Judgment of the Court was delivered by SARKAR J.-This is an appeal against a judgment of the High

facts.text: Bombay High Court answered affirmatively the question: Whether the levy of Rs. 68,501/- as penalty for concealment in the original return for the assessment year 1951-52 is legal?

anchor.surface_text: This is an appeal against a judgment of the High Court at Bombay given on a case stated to it under the Income-tax Act and answering in the affirmative the following question Whether the levy of Rs. 68,501/- as penalty for companycealment in the original return for the assessment year 1951-52 is legal?

facts.text: Assessee is a firm carrying on business at Surat with a branch at Bangkok exporting cloth from India; branch made local purchases and sales.

anchor.surface_text: The question arose, in the assessment of the appellant, a firm, for the year 1951-52 in respect of which the accounting year was the calendar year 1950. The assessee carried on business at Surat it had a branch at Bangkok to which it exported cloth from India.

facts.text: Bangkok branch business in abeyance during last world war, restarted after termination of hostilities.

anchor.surface_text: The branch also made purchases locally and sold them. During the last world war the business at Bangkok had been in abeyance but it was re- started after the termination of the hostilities.

facts.text: For assessment year 1949-50, assessee did not include Bangkok branch profit in return, stated books not available, profit assessed on estimate basis at 5% on exports to Bangkok.

anchor.surface_text: In its return for the assessment year 1949-50 the assessee did number include any profit of the Bangkok branch but stated that the books of account of the Bangkok branch were number available and that therefore its profit might number be assessed on an estimate basis subject to action under S. 34 or 35 on production of statement of account.

facts.text: Accounting year for assessment year 1951-52 was calendar year 1950.

anchor.surface_text: for the year 1951-52 in respect of which the accounting year was the calendar year 1950.

facts.text: For assessment year 1950-51, no reference to Bangkok branch in return, similar estimate made.

anchor.surface_text: The assessment was there- upon made on the basis of profit at 5 on the export to Bangkok branch appearing in the Surat books. For the year 1950-51 again there was numberreference to the Bangkok branch in the return and a similar estimate was made for this year also.

facts.text: For assessment year 1951-52, Bangkok business profits not shown in return.

anchor.surface_text: For the year, 1951-52 also the Bangkok business profits were number shown

facts.text: Income-tax Officer issued notice under s. 22(4) on January 11, 1952 to produce profit and loss account, balance-sheet and relevant books.

anchor.surface_text: but on January 11, 1952, the Income-tax Officer issued a numberice to the assessee under s. 22 4  of the Act to produce the profits and loss account and balance-sheet with the relevant books.

facts.text: On January 29, 1952, assessee stated books at Bangkok, partner Hatimbhai A. Malbary needs to go personally, promised to produce accounts for 1950 next year.

anchor.surface_text: The assessee excused itself by alleging on January 29, 1952 that the books were at Bangkok and the profit and loss account and the balance- sheet companyld number be drawn up unless its partner, Hatimbhai A. Malbary, went there personally and there was numbercertainty as to when he would go there and promising that in the following year these accounts for the calendar year 1950 would be produced.

facts.text: Income-tax Officer estimated sales of Bangkok branch at Rs. 7,50,000 and net profits at 5% thereon i.e. Rs. 37,500; assessment made on January 31, 1952.

anchor.surface_text: Thereupon the Income-tax Officer made an estimate of the sales of the Bangkok branch at Rs. 7,50,000 and of the net profits at 5 thereon, amounting to Rs. 37, 5001-. This assessment was made on January 31, 1952.

facts.text: On January 31, 1952, Income-tax Officer issued notice under s. 28(3) to show cause why penalty under s.28(1)(c) for concealment of 1950 income not be levied.

anchor.surface_text: On the same day he issued a numberice under s. 28 3  of the Act requiring the assessee to show cause why a penalty under s.28 1  c  for companycealment of the particulars of the income of 1950 should number be levied.

facts.text: Assessee heard on notice, Income-tax Officer imposed penalty of Rs.20,000 on January 22, 1954 as explanation not acceptable.

anchor.surface_text: The assessee was heard on this numberice and on January 22, 1954, the Income-tax Officer imposed a penalty of Rs.20,000 on it as its explanation was number acceptable.

facts.text: For assessment year 1952-53, assessee produced accounts and books of Bangkok branch on August 17, 1953 showing profit of Rs. 1,25,520 for calendar year 1950.

anchor.surface_text: The Income-tax Officer was however insistent and, therefore, after various adjournments, the assessee had on August 17, 1953 to produce the accounts and books of the Bangkok branch. It appeared from these books that in the calendar year 1950 the assessee had made a profit of Rs. 1,25,520/-.

facts.text: Income-tax Officer commenced proceedings under s. 34 for assessment year 1951-52, assessee submitted return with correct profits for 1950.

anchor.surface_text: The Income-tax Officer thereupon companymenced proceedings under s. 34 of the Act against the assessee in respect of the assessment year 1951- 52 and gave numberice to the assessee to submit a return. The assessee then submitted a return stating therein companyrectly the profits for the calendar year 1950.

facts.text: On April 8, 1954, further notice under s. 28(3) issued to show cause why penalty for deliberate concealment; penalty of Rs. 68,501 imposed on February 28, 1957.

anchor.surface_text: The Income-tax Officer companypleted that assessment after directing the .issue of a further numberice under s. 28 3  on April 8, 1954 requiring the assessee to show cause why penalty should number be levied for deliberately companycealing the particulars of his income of 1950. Pursuant to this numberice the Income-tax Officer passed another order on February 28, 1957 imposing a penalty of Rs. 68,501.

facts.text: Assessee appealed both penalty orders to Appellate Assistant Commissioner, appeals rejected.

anchor.surface_text: So there were two orders of penalty. The assessee appealed to the Appellate Assistant Commissioner against both the aforesaid orders of penalty but the appeals were rejected.

facts.text: Income-tax Appellate Tribunal remitted the Rs. 20,000 penalty, confirmed Rs. 68,501 penalty.

anchor.surface_text: The Tribunal observed, It is indeed difficult to understand the action of the Department in splitting up one offence into two proceedings. ... The levy of Rs. 20,000 has to be remitted in full. The levy of Rs. 68,501 is entirely different. ... The penalty is number at all excessive and accordingly companyfirmed.

facts.text: Revenue authorities never questioned the cancellation of the first penalty order of Rs. 20,000.

anchor.surface_text: The revenue authorities never questioned the cancellation of the first order of penalty.

facts.text: Reference to High Court on question regarding penalty of Rs. 68,501 only.

anchor.surface_text: Thereafter the asseseee obtained a reference to the High Court of the question which we have set out at the beginning of this judgement. That question, it will be numbericed, referred only to the penalty of Rs. 68,501

facts.text: In s.34 return, assessee furnished correct particulars and produced books, no default therein.

anchor.surface_text: It has to be observed that in the return that was filed in the proceedings started under s. 34, the assessee furnished companyrect particulars and it also produced the books. So it had number companymitted any default in companynection therewith.

facts.text: Tribunal found as fact that assessee knew profits were Rs. 1,25,520, did not disclose originally, permitted estimate of Rs. 37,500.

anchor.surface_text: The assessee knew-and this is what was found by the Tribunal and that is a finding of fact which is binding on a Court in a reference-that its profits were Rs. 1,25,520/and it had number disclosed that profit originally number produced the relevant books but permitted the Incometax Officer to proceed on an estimate of that profit at Rs. 37,500/-.

facts.text: High Court held that two penalties could not be levied on identical facts but penalties here not on same facts; original on estimate, second after full facts.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court agreed with the companytention of the assessee that two penalties companyld number be levied in respect of identical facts but it held that the penalties in this case had number been levied on the same facts. It observed that the original assessment was solely on the basis of an estimate and the second assessment was after knowledge of the full facts of the companycealed income.

issues.text: Whether the levy of Rs. 68,501/- as penalty for concealment in the original return for the assessment year 1951-52 is legal?

anchor.surface_text: Whether the levy of Rs. 68,501/- as penalty for concealment in the original return for the assessment year 1951-52 is legal?

issues.text: Whether two penalties could be levied in respect of identical facts or the same concealment?

anchor.surface_text: It was contended in the High Court that in respect of the same concealment there were thus two penalties involved, namely, one of Rs. 20,000 and the other of Rs. 68,501/-. The High Court agreed with the contention of the assessee that two penalties could not be levied in

issues.text: Whether there was jurisdiction to make the second order of penalty while the first order stood?

anchor.surface_text: In this Court Mr. Kolah has urged that the second order for penalty was illegal because there was one concealment and in respect of that an order for penalty of Rs. 20,000/- had earlier been made. He contended that there was no jurisdiction to make the second order

issues.text: Whether the Income-tax Officer was in possession of the full facts which would have justified the imposition of the higher penalty when the first order of penalty was passed?

anchor.surface_text: It was also said that when the first order of penalty was passed the Income-tax Officer was in possession of the full facts which would have justified the imposition of the higher penalty. It was pointed out that the first order of penalty was passed on January 22 1954

issues.text: Whether the qualification on the Income-tax Officer's power to levy penalty under Section 28 in Section 34 proceedings - that no penalty if default known when passing final order in prior proceeding - applies?

anchor.surface_text: There may be one possible qualification of his power, and that is when the default or the act which is the basis of the imposition of the penalty was within the knowledge of the officer who passed the final order in the prior proceeding and if that, officer had failed

arguments.claim: Two penalties cannot be levied in respect of the same concealment

anchor.surface_text: It was contended in the High Court that in respect of the same concealment there were thus two penalties involved, namely, one of Rs. 20,000 and the other of Rs. 68,501/-. The High Court agreed with the contention of the assessee that two penalties could not be levied in

court_response_anchor.surface_text: er passed another order on February 28, 1957 imposing a penalty of Rs. 68,501. So there were two orders of penalty. The assessee appealed to the Appel

arguments.court_reasoning: Agreed no two penalties on identical facts, but here penalties not on same facts as first based on estimate and second on full facts

arguments.claim: Penalties in this case had not been levied on the same facts; original on estimate, second after knowledge of full facts of concealed income

anchor.surface_text: The High Court agreed with the contention of the assessee that two penalties could not be levied in respect of identical facts but it held that the penalties in this case had not been levied on the same facts. It observed that the original assessment was solely on the basis of an estimate and the second assessment was after knowledge of the full facts of the concealed income.

arguments.claim: Second order for penalty illegal because one concealment and first penalty order already made; no jurisdiction to make second while first stood, second is nullity even if first later cancelled

anchor.surface_text: In this Court Mr. Kolah has urged that the second order for penalty was illegal because there was one concealment and in respect of that an order for penalty of Rs. 20,000/- had earlier been made. He contended that there was no jurisdiction to make the second order of penalty while the first order stood and for that reason the second order must be treated as a nullity.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: o the High Court of the question which we have set out at the beginning of this judgement. That question, it will be numbericed, referred only to the

arguments.court_reasoning: Not question of jurisdiction but two orders cannot stand together; ITO entitled to pass second higher penalty upon true facts; first cancelled, no objection, so only one valid order

arguments.claim: When first penalty order passed, ITO in possession of full facts justifying higher penalty; no right to later change the order

anchor.surface_text: It was also said that when the first order of penalty was passed the Income-tax Officer was in possession of the full facts which would have justified the imposition of the higher penalty. It was pointed out that the first order of penalty was passed on January 22 1954 while the books disclosing the real state of affairs had been produced before the Income-tax Officer on August 17, 1953.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: sessee knew-and this is what was found by the Tribunal and that is a finding of fact which is binding on a Court in a reference-that its profits were

arguments.court_reasoning: First penalty pursuant to notice of Jan 31 1952 and explanation March 11 1952; books produced later for different year; assessee never heard on concealment from those books

court_response_anchor.surface_text: other of Rs. 68,501/-. The High Court agreed with the companytention of the assessee that two penalties companyld number be levied in respect of ident

arguments.court_reasoning: Observation obiter, not subscribed to; even if correct, inapplicable as no knowledge of concealment at final prior order of Jan 31 1952

arguments.claim: Levy of first penalty of Rs.20,000 has no basis as based on estimate under s.23(3), no guilt established yet

anchor.surface_text: The Tribunal observed, It is indeed difficult to understand the action of the Department in splitting up one offence into two proceedings. ... The levy of Rs. 20,000 has to be remitted in full.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: produce the accounts and books of the Bangkok branch. It appeared from these b

arguments.court_reasoning: Revenue authorities never questioned the cancellation

arguments.claim: Second penalty of Rs.68,501 confirmed as ITO had definite knowledge of profit Rs.1,25,520, proving concealment guilt; penalty not excessive

anchor.surface_text: The levy of Rs. 68,501 is entirely different. With the definite knowledge that the Income-tax Officer had obtained that the profit for the year was Rs. 1,25,520 he has clearly proved the guilt of concealment against the assessee The penalty is not at all excessive and accordingly confirmed.

arguments.claim: Assessee knew profits were Rs.1,25,520 but did not disclose originally, did not produce books, permitted estimate of Rs.37,500

anchor.surface_text: The assessee knew-and this is what was found by the Tribunal and that is a finding of fact which is binding on a Court in a reference-that its profits were Rs. 1,25,520/and it had not disclosed that profit originally not produced the relevant books but permitted the Incometax Officer to proceed on an estimate of that profit at Rs. 37,500/-.

arguments.claim: Penalty under the section related to amount of tax evaded if concealment succeeded; ITO entitled to impose higher penalty on true facts, even without recalling first

anchor.surface_text: The penalty under the section has to be related to the amount of the tax which would have been evaded if the assessee had got away with the concealment. In this case having assessed the income by an estimate, the Income-tax Officer levied a penalty on the basis of that estimate. Later when he ascertained the true facts and realised that a much higher penalty could have been imposed, he was entitled to recall the earlier order and pass another order imposing the higher penalty.

arguments.claim: Second notice under s.28(3) in respect of original concealment as no default in s.34 return

anchor.surface_text: It has to be observed that in the return that was filed in the proceedings started under s. 34, the assessee furnished correct particulars and it also produced the books. So it had not committed any default in connection therewith. The notice must therefore be taken to have been in respect of the original concealment of the income.

holdings.text: The levy of Rs. 68,501/- as penalty for concealment in the original return for the assessment year 1951-52 is legal.

anchor.surface_text: we have only one order and that for the reasons earlier stated is, in our view, a legal order. It was also said that when the first order of penalty was passed the Income-tax Officer was in possession of the full facts which would have justified the imposition of the higher penalty.

holdings.reasoning_summary: First penalty cancelled without objection; second imposed on true facts with full jurisdiction; assessee concealed known profits originally; Tribunal finding binding.

holdings.text: The notice under s. 28(3) issued on April 8, 1954 was in respect of the original concealment of income, as no default in s.34 return.

anchor.surface_text: It has to be observed that in the return that was filed in the proceedings started under s. 34, the assessee furnished correctly the particulars and it also produced the books. So it had not committed any default in connection therewith.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Assessee provided correct particulars and books in s.34 proceedings, so notice pertains to original default.

holdings.text: Tribunal's finding that assessee knew profits were Rs. 1,25,520, did not disclose them originally, and permitted estimate is a binding fact finding.

anchor.surface_text: The assessee knew-and this is what was found by the Tribunal and that is a finding of fact which is binding on a Court in a reference-that its profits were Rs. 1,25,520/- and it had not disclosed that profit originally not produced the relevant books but permitted the Income-tax Officer to proceed on an estimate of that profit at Rs. 37,500/-

holdings.reasoning_summary: Standard doctrine that Tribunal fact findings bind courts in references under Income-tax Act.

holdings.text: Two orders of penalty cannot stand together in respect of the same concealment.

anchor.surface_text: It may be that in respect of the same concealment two orders of penalty would not stand but it is not a question of jurisdiction.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Agrees with principle no double penalty on identical facts; first cancelled, only one remains.

holdings.text: Income-tax Officer had full jurisdiction to impose second higher penalty order even without recalling the earlier one.

anchor.surface_text: He had full jurisdiction to make the second order and he would not lose that jurisdiction because he had omitted to recall the earlier order, though it may be that the two orders could not be enforced simultaneously or stand together.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Jurisdiction not lost by omission to recall; two orders cannot coexist but second valid upon true facts.

holdings.text: Income-tax Officer entitled to impose higher penalty upon ascertaining true facts after initial estimate-based penalty.

anchor.surface_text: The penalty under the section has to be related to the amount of the tax which would have been evaded if the assessee had got away with the concealment. In this case having assessed the income by an estimate, the Income-tax Officer levied a penalty on the basis of that estimate. Later when he ascertained the true facts and realised that a much higher penalty could have been imposed, he was entitled to recall the earlier order and pass another order imposing the higher penalty.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Penalty proportional to evaded tax; power to supersede estimate-based penalty with fact-based higher one.

holdings.text: The qualification on ITO's power stated in Govinderajulu (no penalty if default known at prior final order) is obiter and not subscribed to.

anchor.surface_text: We do not think that Rajamannar C.J. wished to state this qualification on the power of the Income-tax Officer as a proposition of law. It was not certainly necessary for the purposes of the case before him. We do not wish to be understood as subscribing to it as at present advised.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Observation unnecessary to that decision; court declines to adopt as law.

holdings.text: Even if Govinderajulu qualification applies, inapplicable here as ITO had no knowledge of full concealment at prior final assessment order of Jan 31, 1952.

anchor.surface_text: Now in the present case the final order in the prior assessment proceedings was made on January 31, 1952 and on that date the Income-tax Officer had no knowledge of the concealment of income of Rs. 1,25,520. Therefore it seems to us that the observation of Rajamannar C.J. does not assist Mr. Kolah.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Knowledge of true profits came later; first penalty notice unrelated to later books.

precedents.citation: C. V. Govinderajulu Iyer v. Commissioner of Income tax, Madras

anchor.surface_text: In support of this contention reference was made to C. V. Govinderajulu Iyer v. Commissioner of Income tax, Madras. There it was argued that the original proceeding under s. 23 3  and a proceeding under s. 34 in respect of the same period were different and in the latter proceeding a penalty companyld number be imposed for a companycealment

precedents.case_name: C. V. Govinderajulu Iyer v. Commissioner of Income tax, Madras
precedents.cited_proposition: Income-tax Officer is competent to levy penalty under s.28(1) in s.34 proceedings for concealment relating to the original assessment proceedings for the same period, subject to possible qualification if the default was known to the officer in the prior proceeding and he failed to act then
precedents.cited_holding: so long as the proceedings under Section 34 relate to the assessment for the same period as the original assessment, the Income-tax Officer will be competent to levy a penalty on any ground open to him under Section 28 1 , even though it relates to the prior proceeding

justification_sets.label: No Double Penalty for Identical Facts support
ITO Power to Recall and Revise Penalty Order support

anchor.surface_text: The penalty under the section has to be related to the amount of the tax which would have been evaded if the assessee had got away with the concealment. In this case having assessed the income by an estimate, the Income-tax Officer levied a penalty on the basis of that estimate. Later when he ascertained the true facts and realised that a much higher penalty could have been imposed, he was entitled to recall the earlier order and pass another order imposing the higher penalty.

anchor.surface_text: We do not think that Rajamannar C.J. wished to state this qualification on the power of the Income-tax Officer as a proposition of law. It was not certainly necessary for the purposes of the case before him. We do not wish to be understood as subscribing to it as at present advised.

However, in the present case the earlier order having been cancelled and numberobjection to the cancellation having been taken, we have only one order and that for the reasons earlier stated is, in our view, a legal order.

anchor.surface_text: Now in the present case the final order in the prior assessment proceedings was made on January 31, 1952 and on that date the Income-tax Officer had no knowledge of the concealment of income of Rs. 1,25,520. Therefore it seems to us that the observation of Rajamannar C.J. does not assist Mr. Kolah.

However, in the present case the earlier order having been cancelled and numberobjection to the cancellation having been taken, we have only one order and that for the reasons earlier stated is, in our view, a legal order.
